content:
From a docOps perspective, it's far easier for me when I work on ETH2 REST API than on the ETH1 JSON-RPC one...
ETH1 API is now 6yo and we learned how to deal with it without a clear spec, most of the tools now know how to get around the few issues and the libraries are stable... and ETH2 is coming with a REST API that we document and spec using OpenAPI 3.
Is it worth putting a lot of energy in a spec for RPC?
Shouldn‚Äôt we spec a REST API for ETH1 instead?
That would make it consistent with ETH2 so that when ETH1 and ETH2 will work together (I don‚Äôt know, in the sharding phase for example), it will help to have a unified interface? And even if they don‚Äôt work together, it would enable devs and users to only handle one kind of API.
The effort required to update spec and all RPC implementations is probably close to implementing the same endpoint using REST.
The effort required to update client applications would also be optional and would minimize the impact of the spec as apps could continue to use the current JSON-RPC API if it‚Äôs enough for them. They could switch to the REST/OpenAPI as needed, later.
The effort required for new client projects would be smaller if they directly implement REST/OpenAPI because it is easier than JSON-RPC. 
We already did this when we implemented GraphQL, same sources, different APIs, ‚Äújust‚Äù an overlay change in the code. Having a REST api alongside RPC (for backward compatibility of course) would not be a very different effort on the node developers side and would prepare for the future, give more choice to users, help using well known and user friendly documentation and code generation tools‚Ä¶ and it would make my days a lot better I admit üòâ

author: jgm
content:
For what it's worth, JSON-RPC has always felt to me like the worst of all worlds.

One thing I'm not sure is present for any ETH1 API proposal is a list of the requirements.  We spent more time going back and forth on them than picking the particular transport/protocol.
